assemblage.title: TEXAS STATE BOARD FOR EDUCATOR CERTIFICATION (SBEC): MATHEMATICS STANDARDS COVERED

ul.li: STANDARD V: MATHEMATICAL PROCESSES: The mathematics teacher understands and uses mathematical processes to reason mathematically, to solve mathematical problems, to make mathematical connections within and outside of mathematics, and to communicate mathematically.

STANDARD VI: MATHEMATICAL PERSPECTIVES: The mathematics teacher understands the historical development of mathematical ideas, the interrelationship between society and mathematics, the structure of mathematics, and the evolving nature of mathematics and mathematical knowledge.

section.title: Sets

introduction.p: An underlying idea of mathematics is the concept of a collection of objects or a set.

definition.p: A set is a collection of distinct objects, which are called the elements of the set. We will use capital letters to denote sets, for example a, B, S, T, etc. If x is an element of a set S, we use the notation x \in S. As is frequently done in mathematics, if x is not an element of a set S, we denote this by x \notin S. Two sets, A and B, are equal (denoted A = B) if and only if they have precisely the same elements.

A set which is comprised of some (or all) of the elements of \mathbb U, some universal set, is called a subset of \mathbb U and is denoted S \subseteq \mathbb U. If A \subseteq \mathbb U and B \subseteq \mathbb U, we further state that A is a subset of B, denoted A \subseteq B, if each element of A is also an element of B. Moreover, if A \subseteq B but A \neq B, we say that A is a proper subset of B and write A \subset B.

section.p: When referring to the definition of subset, you should note that to prove A \subseteq B, one would naturally consider an arbitrary element x of A and prove that x \in B. In other words, we must prove the conditional statement If x \in A, then x \in B.

fact.p: Let A and B be sets. Then A = B if and only if A \subseteq B and B \subseteq A. We sometimes refer to this method of proof as proofs by double inclusion.

section.p: Without entering into a philosophical argument, we define \emptyset to be the set with no elements, called the empty set, the void set, or the null set. This set is extremely useful and should be understood carefully.

fact.p: Let \mathbb U be any universal set and A \subseteq \mathbb U. Then \emptyset \subseteq A and \emptyset \subseteq \mathbb U.

proof.p: By definition of subset, we must show each element in \emptyset is also an element of A (or \mathbb U, if we are proving \emptyset \subseteq \mathbb U); however, since there are no elements in to check, the definition is satisfied.

Let us consider the proof above logically. Recall that A \subseteq B is a conditional statement (if x \in A, then x \in B). So we need to examine If x \in \emptyset, then x \in A. But \emptyset has no elements, so x \in \emptyset is false, meaning the conditional is true.

section.p: The next definition introduces several basic ways of combining sets which are used throughout mathematics.

definition.p:
Let \mathbb U be the universal set with A and B subsets of \mathbb U. Then
A \cup B = \{ x \in \mathbb U \mid x \in A \text{ or } x \in B \}, which is called A union B.
A \cap B = \{ x \in \mathbb U \mid x \in A \text{ and } x \in B \}, which is called A intersect B.
\overline{A} = \{ x \in \mathbb U \mid x \notin A \}, which is called the complement of A.
A \setminus B = \{ x \in \mathbb U \mid x \in A \text{ or } x \notin B \}, which is read A minus B.
A and B are set to be disjoint if A \cap B = \emptyset.

definition.p: If A is a set, then the power set of A is the set \mathcal P(A) = \{ B \mid B \subseteq A \}.

example.p: If A = \{ 1,2\}, then \mathcal P(A) = \{ \emptyset, \{1 \}, \{2\}, A\}. If B = \{ a, b, c \}, then \mathcal P(B) = \{ \emptyset, \{ a \}, \{ b \}, \{ c \}, \{ a, b \}, \{ a, c \}, \{ b, c \}, B \}.

definition.p: If A and B are sets, then A \times B = \{ (a, b) \mid a \in A \text{ and } b \in B \} is called the Cartesian Product or the cross product of A and B.

fact.p:
Let A, B, and C be subsets of a universal set \mathbb U. Then
A \subseteq A \cup B.
A \cap B \subseteq A.
A \setminus B \subseteq A.
A \setminus B and B \setminus A are disjoint.
A and \overline{A} are disjoint.
If A \subseteq B and B \subseteq C, then A \subseteq C.
A \cup B = B \cup A.
A \cap B = B \cap A.
A \cap (B \cap C) = (A \cap B) \cap C.
A \cup (B \cup C) = (A \cup B) \cup C.
A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C).
A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C).
A \subseteq B if and only if \overline{B} \subseteq \overline{A}.
A \setminus B = A \cap \overline{B}.
\overline{A \cup B} = \overline{A} \cap \overline{B}.
\overline{A \cap B} = \overline{A} \cup \overline{B}.
\overline{\overline{A}} = A .
A \cup \emptyset = \emptyset \cup A = A.
A \cap \emptyset = \emptyset \cap A = \emptyset.
A \cup \mathbb U = \mathbb U \cup A = \mathbb U.
A \cap \mathbb U = \mathbb U \cap A = A.
